name: IMRC
mission: IMRC has been working for over four decades to support Muslims and minorities in India. We fund education, healthcare, water access, economic programs, and emergency relief.
theoryOfChange: IMRC states it supports Muslims and minorities in India by funding year-round projects in education, healthcare, water access, economic programs, and emergency relief through 100+ partners on the ground, aiming to create real, measurable change.
zakatClaimEvidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat (Source: https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Good donor alignment with manageable risk. Evidence quality is solid but still evolving in places.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1); Asnaf: fuqara (+5); Strong humanitarian service (+4)
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 34/50: HIGH Muslim donor fit, advocacy cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: Separate restricted/endowment funds from operating reserves and publish a clear reserve-use policy.
components.name: Financial Health

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities shows strong impact and good alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat (Source: https://www.imrcusa.org/zakat)

all_citations.claim: IMRC reported total revenue of $13,833,809 and a program expense ratio of 89.8%.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and follows specific asnaf categories for distribution.
IMRC holds 55.7 months of working capital and a fundraising efficiency of $0.01 per $1 raised.
IMRC provided meals, safe water access, and medical treatment to patients in 2019.
The organization supported students and provided water access during the 2020 fiscal year.
IMRC continued its impact by providing meals and healthcare treatments to beneficiaries in 2021.
The charity has a historical track record of building wells and distributing meals to those in need.
IMRC offers various donation options and giving methods for supporters.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: IMRC earns a GMG score of 73/100 due to its high financial efficiency and direct service impact, though its overall score is moderated by medium data confidence and advocacy-focused alignment.
areas_for_improvement: Enhancing data transparency to improve the medium data confidence level.
Providing more recent impact reporting beyond the 2021 annual report cycle.

dimension_explanations.alignment: IMRC shows high donor fit for those seeking to support Indian minority rights and Zakat-eligible causes [2][9]. The organization's long track record in advocacy and emergency relief addresses urgent cause areas, though its alignment score of 34/50 reflects the specific nature of its advocacy-based mission [1][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high impact through direct service delivery, including treating thousands of patients and supporting students across multiple years [4][6][8]. With a total revenue of $13,833,809 and a program expense ratio of 89.8%, IMRC maintains strong financial health and evidence of program effectiveness [1][3].

baseline_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities provides critical humanitarian aid and advocacy to empower India's minority communities through sustainable development.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.8%, ensuring the vast majority of funds reach beneficiaries.
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.01 per $1 raised.
Robust financial stability with 55.7 months of working capital.
baseline_narrative.summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) works to ensure India's Muslims and minorities achieve security, equality, and their rights as citizens [1][3]. The organization operates comprehensive programs in education, healthcare, and emergency relief, maintaining a Zakat-eligible status for eligible donor contributions [2][9].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: IMRC earns a GMG score of 73/100 due to its high financial efficiency and direct service impact, though its overall score is moderated by medium data confidence and advocacy-focused alignment.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization's <cite id="1">89.8% program expense ratio</cite> falls below the <cite id="1">industry standard of 75%</cite> and the <cite id="1">peer median of 89.8%</cite>.
The most recent detailed impact metrics available are from the <cite id="6">2021 Annual Report</cite>, indicating a need for more current outcome data.

bbb_assessment.summary: BBB assessment data is not available for this organization.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization maintains exceptionally high working capital reserves, which provides stability despite revenue fluctuations.
risk_factors: The <cite id="1">89.8% program expense ratio</cite> is significantly lower than the <cite id="1">peer median of 89.8%</cite>.
The organization has experienced a <cite id="1">-10.2% 3-year revenue CAGR</cite>.
case_against.summary: The primary concern for donors is the organization's financial efficiency metrics and recent revenue trends.

confidence.notes: Data confidence is medium due to the lack of recent impact reporting and incomplete third-party ratings.

alignment.explanation: The charity shows high alignment for Muslim donors, offering an explicit <cite id="2">Zakat program</cite> that serves the <cite id="2">fuqara (poor)</cite> through strong humanitarian service in India.
alignment.improvement: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust IMRC due to its long history since <cite id="3">1981</cite> and strong governance, featuring a <cite id="3">14-member board</cite> that is <cite id="3">100% independent</cite>. The organization also has a documented theory of change.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility further, the charity could enhance data transparency by publishing more recent annual reports and detailed financial audits.

impact.explanation: IMRC utilizes a direct service delivery model. While historical impact is significant, such as <cite id="6">treating 183,100 patients</cite> in 2021, the current <cite id="1">89.8% program expense ratio</cite> is below the peer median.
impact.improvement: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Historical outcome tracking available

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service delivery rather than grantmaking.

rich_narrative.headline: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities provides critical humanitarian aid and advocacy to empower India's minority communities through sustainable development.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who are specifically passionate about supporting Muslim and minority communities in India through established, Zakat-eligible humanitarian programs.
donor_motivations: Want to fulfill Zakat obligations while supporting vulnerable populations in India
Value organizations with a long, established history of operation
Prioritize charities with strong financial reserves and stability
giving_considerations: The program expense ratio is lower than industry peers
Recent detailed impact reports are not readily available
Revenue has seen a downward trend over the past three years
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking organizations with the highest possible program expense ratios or those requiring real-time, rigorous academic evidence of impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C indicates that the organization tracks and publishes historical outcome metrics (such as meals provided and patients treated), but lacks recent, rigorous third-party evaluations or RCTs.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: IMRC strives to bring awareness of the status of Muslims and minorities in India with the intention of alleviating poverty through education, healthcare, and emergency relief.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence helps ensure donations create real impact and allows donors to understand the cost-effectiveness of the programs they support.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the organization has significant reserves, the declining revenue trend suggests a need for renewed funding to maintain historical program scale.

organizational_capacity.geographic_reach: India, State of Jammu and Kashmir

peer_comparison.differentiator: IMRC is distinguished by its specific focus on India's Muslim and minority populations and its long operating history since 1981.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar focus on advocacy and legal support, operating at a similar scale.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar focus on advocacy and legal support, but operates at a smaller scale.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Similar focus on advocacy and legal support, operating at a similar scale.

strengths.detail: The organization operates with remarkable efficiency, spending only <cite id="3">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>.
IMRC maintains strong reserves, with <cite id="3">55.7 months of working capital</cite> available for operations.
The organization has demonstrated capacity for large-scale relief, such as providing <cite id="5">over 16 million meals</cite> and supporting <cite id="5">10,000 students</cite> in 2020.

strengths_deep_dive: IMRC demonstrates strong organizational capacity and financial stability. The charity maintains an exceptionally lean fundraising operation, spending just <cite id="3">$0.01 per $1 raised</cite>. This is complemented by robust financial reserves, with <cite id="3">55.7 months of working capital</cite>, ensuring the organization can weather economic fluctuations and respond to sudden emergencies. Furthermore, IMRC's governance structure includes a <cite id="3">14-member board</cite> that is <cite id="3">100% independent</cite>, reflecting strong oversight practices.
rich_narrative.summary: Indian Muslim Relief and Charities (IMRC) provides critical humanitarian aid and advocacy to empower India's minority communities through sustainable development. Founded in <cite id="3">1981</cite>, the organization operates comprehensive programs in education, healthcare, clean water, and emergency relief across <cite id="3">India and the State of Jammu and Kashmir</cite>. In 2023, IMRC reported <cite id="1">$13,833,809 in total revenue</cite>, directing <cite id="1">89.8% to program expenses</cite>. The organization maintains a strong focus on direct service delivery and is <cite id="2">Zakat-eligible</cite>, allowing donors to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting vulnerable populations. IMRC has demonstrated significant scale in its operations, reporting <cite id="6">7.2 million meals provided</cite> and <cite id="6">183,100 patients treated</cite> in its 2021 annual report.
